title: Antaeotricha encyclia
text:
Antaeotricha encyclia is a <a href="species">species</a> of <a href="moth">moth</a> in the family <a href="Depressariidae">Depressariidae</a>. It was described by <a href="Edward%20Meyrick">Edward Meyrick</a> in 1915. It is found in <a href="Colombia">Colombia</a>.
The <a href="wingspan">wingspan</a> is about 28 mm. The <a href="forewings">forewings</a> are ochreous-whitish with a rounded dark fuscous spot on the base of the <a href="Glossary%20of%20entomology%20terms%23costa">costa</a>, and one rather smaller at one-sixth. There is an ochreous-yellow scale-projection on the <a href="Glossary%20of%20entomology%20terms%23dorsum">dorsal</a> edge at one-third and an indistinct streak of brownish and dark fuscous scales running from the first costal spot to this, a spot towards the costa at one-third, one on the fold beneath this, one in the disc before the middle, one on the dorsum beyond the middle, a curved series of cloudy marks from beneath the costa before the middle to the dorsum at four-fifths, preceded by two transversely placed cloudy dark grey dots on the end of the cell. There are subterminal and terminal fasciae of fuscous suffusion, the first not reaching the costa and the terminal area is yellowish-tinged. The hindwings are whitish-grey, the costal margin expanded to the middle, with long projecting ochreous-whitish hairscales suffused with grey beneath, and a moderately long ochreous-whitish subcostal hairpencil lying beneath the forewings.
